Description: Limestone corner fragment, possibly a plinth or an offering table, inscribed with the cartouche of Akhenaten. On top of the fragment is a circular shallow recess and partial remains of another recess with a straight edge. The front edge is smoothed, while the left side contains a partial horizontal line of incised text. The remaining two sides are heavily damaged with no surviving inscription, and the corners of the stone are also chipped. On the base of the fragment, ‘Tell Amarna’ is written in red ink.
Curator's comments: The text concludes with the throne name of Akhenaten and the name of Kiya, his lesser wife. It has been suggested that the offering table could once have been supported by a standing figure of Kiya, though at Amarna this is more often found in representations of either Akhenaten or Nefertiti (Reeves 1988). Further Bibliography: C.N. Reeves, 1988. ‘New Light on Kiya from Texts in the British Museum’, Journal of Egyptian Archaeology Vol. 74, p. 92-93, p. 100, Pl. XV, no. 2-4.
